review.title: Finding the different patterns in buildings data using bag of words representation with clustering
review.abstract: The understanding of the buildings operation has become a challenging task due to the large amount of data recorded in energy efficient buildings. Still, today the experts use visual tools for analyzing the data. In order to make the task realistic, a method has been proposed in this paper to automatically detect the different patterns in buildings. The K Means clustering is used to automatically identify the ON (operational) cycles of the chiller. In the next step the ON cycles are transformed to symbolic representation by using Symbolic Aggregate Approximation (SAX) method. Then the SAX symbols are converted to bag of words representation for hierarchical clustering. Moreover, the proposed technique is applied to real life data of adsorption chiller. Additionally, the results from the proposed method and dynamic time warping (DTW) approach are also discussed and compared.

metadata.title: Finding the different patterns in buildings data using bag of words representation with clustering

sections.heading: A. Adsorption Chillers
sections.text: The designation conventions used in Figure 1 correspond to task 38 of the IEA programme for solar heating and cooling [24]. The operation of the adsorption chillers can be described in the following steps [25] 1. The process of water evaporation takes place in the lower chamber, the so-called evaporator, which cools the water in the low-temperature cycle. 2. The evaporated water is condensed in the middle chamber using silica gels.3. The adsorbed water is dessorbed with a certain heat provided by the hot water cycle (HT).4. The deadsorbed water is condensed and returned to the evaporator.

sections.heading: B. Data Description
sections.text: The data for 2010 will be used for the conceptual proof proposed in this paper, as can be seen in Figure 2. Figure 2 clearly shows that the cooling operation is mainly recorded during the summer season. It is significant to note that there are days when little or no data is recorded due to communication line malfunctions or other unknown errors. IV. METHODOLOGY In this section, the methodology proposed in this paper is discussed. The first step in analyzing the data is always the pre-processing and finding of outliers. The data used has already been processed, so it can be used without the pre-processing step.

sections.heading: A. ON State (Operational) detection using K-Means clustering
sections.text: Since the data in the two states (ON / OFF) of the cooler vary greatly, we can bundle the data into two clusters. K-Mean Clustering with two cluster and euclidean distance settings is used to detect the ON / OFF state. After detecting the ON / OFF state at any time, the successive ON state is marked as an ON cycle. The same process is performed for all successive ON / OFF states. ON status is more important than the OFF cycle to determine the performance of the cooler.

sections.heading: B. Symbolic Aggregate Approximation (SAX) tranformation

The normalized ON cycle data () are first broken down into sub-sequences that do not overlap in m. This process is called chunking, and the period length P is based on the application in which it is used [3]. For this paper, P is selected as 4 minutes based on the recording time interval of 4 minutes. The x-axis in Figure 3 represents the 4-minute interval of the P is then displayed as a sequence of the 4-minute interval of each P.

In order to handle ON cycles with different length of time, Eq.4 has been modified as Eq.5, where N is the number of ticks in the ON cycle. sections.heading: D. Key Steps in Methodology
sections.text: The different results are discussed as follows:

sections.heading: C. Hierarchical Clustering
sections.text: The hierarchical clustering is applied using Dynamic Time Warping and the suggested method of bag representation (BoWR) method. Figure 6 shows the results of clustering with DTW and Figure 7 describes the results with BoWR. Both methods have correctly classified the cycles. BoWR's first advantage over DTW is dimensional reduction, since each cycle is represented with significantly less data. Second, the comparison of cluster performance with both methods shows the cophenetic coefficients [7] was calculated for hierarchical clustering. Cophenetic correlation shows that the cluster tree has a strong correlation with the distances between objects in the distance vector. Table 3 shows the cophenetic coefficients with different hierarchical clustering methods for BoWR and DTW techniques. BoWR has a strong correlation with all other objects in the cluster method.

referenceMentions.context: A lot of raw data is recorded during the monitoring of the energy efficient buildings [1].
The experts in the field usually analyze the data using different visualization tools [2].
The use of different data mining techniques can help in finding the different patterns in the buildings data, particularly clustering [3]–[5].

The similarities can be found by using simple Euclidean distance between two time series data, but the problem will be even a slighter shift of data can lead to erroneous results [6].
There is another method called dynamic time warping (DTW) which overcomes the problem by using dynamic programming technique with defining the best alignment in data [17].
In [6] the comparison of algorithms (Euclidean, DTW, wavelets) with hierarchical cluster for finding different time series is done.
The bag of words model is used in several fields for classification [18].
The bag of words model can also be used with clustering to enhance the algorithm for finding the similarities between the time series data [6].
SAX is a category of Piecewise Aggregate Approximation (PAA) representation and is used extensively in various applications [19].

metadata.abstractText: The understanding of the buildings operation has become a challenging task due to the large amount of data recorded in energy efficient buildings. Still, today the experts use visual tools for analyzing the data. In order to make the task realistic, a method has been proposed in this paper to automatically detect the different patterns in buildings. The K-Means clustering is used to automatically identify the ON (operational) cycles of the chiller. In the next step the ON cycles are transformed to symbolic representation by using Symbolic Aggregate Approximation (SAX) method. Then the SAX symbols are converted to bag of words representation for hierarchical clustering. Moreover, the proposed technique is applied to real life data of adsorption chiller. Additionally, the results from the proposed method and dynamic time warping (DTW) approach are also discussed and compared. Keywords— Building energy performance; Fault detection and diagnosis (FDD); clustering; symbolic aggregate approximation (SAX); Bag of words representation (BoWR); hierarchical clustering; Dynamic time warping (DTW); Coefficient of Performance (COP)
